choices.D: Enable Auto-negotiate and Autokey Keep Alive on the phase 2 configuration of both tunnels.
choices.A: Configure a higher distance on the static route for the primary tunnel, and a lower distance on the static route for the secondary tunnel.
choices.C: Configure a lower distance on the static route for the primary tunnel, and a higher distance on the static route for the secondary tunnel.

discussion.content: B & C is correct. FortiGate_Infrastructure_6.4 page 219 for "B" and 243 for "C"

Ok to answer this question is B and C.
B because the customer requires the tunnels to notify when a tunnel goes down. DPD is designed for that purpose. To send a packet over a firewall to determine a failover for the next tunnel after a specific amount of time of not receiving a response from its peer.
C remember when it comes to choosing a route with regards to Administrative Distance. The route with the lowest distance for that particular route will be chosen. So, by configuring a lower routing distance on the primary tunnel, means that the primary tunnel will be chosen to route packets towards their destination.

questions.question_text:
A network administrator wants to set up redundant IPsec VPN tunnels on FortiGate by using two IPsec VPN tunnels and static routes.
✑ All traffic must be routed through the primary tunnel when both tunnels are up.
✑ The secondary tunnel must be used only if the primary tunnel goes down.
✑ In addition, FortiGate should be able to detect a dead tunnel to speed up tunnel failover.
Which two key configuration changes are needed on FortiGate to meet the design requirements? (Choose two.)

choices.B: port1-vlan10 and port2-vlan10 are part of the same broadcast domain.
choices.A: Traffic between port2 and port2-vlan1 is allowed by default.
choices.D: port1-vlan1 and port2-vlan1 can be assigned in the same VDOM or to different VDOMs.

discussion.content:
The answer must be C and D.
For A - traffic between interfaces is not allowed by default.
For B - Port1-vlan10 and port-2vlan10 are not in the same broadcast domain since the subnet is different.

comments.content: fortigate ports are in different broadcast domains. so how port1 and port 2 are in same broadcast domains? ı am not sure abot the answer, but B seems incorrect to me.
each VLAN forms a separate broadcast domain | Pag 154
B & D seems to me the correct answers

broadcast domains are discussed in transparent-mode, no IP is assigned to the interfaces in this mode, much less considering that 10.1.10.1/24 is in the same broadcast domain as 10.0.10.1/24 B is surely incorrect.

discussion.content:
B & D is correct.
FortiGate_Infrastructure_6.4 page 127 for "D" and page 154 for "B"

comments.content:
A wrong most of all because traffic between interfaces not allowed by default.
And D is correct for the sake of the answer... But in reality, the two vlans couldn't exist on the same vdom unless the subnets matched.

discussion.content:
A. WRONG Because they are different subnets, this will not work work.
B. WRONG The interfaces can only be a part of the same broadcast domain if the Fortigate is in Transparent mode. If the Fortigate was in transpararent mode, however, the interfaces would not be assigned IP addresses.
C. CORRECT Physical interface is native VLAN.
D. CORRECT In NAT mode, which this obviously is, interfaces can be moved around. And even multi-VDOM VLAN sub-interfaces can belong in different VDOMs.

I agree with aads... "For A - traffic between interfaces is not allowed by default.

CD is correct
A is wrong, different interfaces are not allowed by default
B is wrong, because physical interfaces with SAME VLAN do not have to belong to the same broadcast domain. We don't know if they connect to the same switch. Also the IP subnet is different another clue

B & D ----Creating VLAN subinterfaces with the same VLAN ID doesn’t create an internal connection between them. For example,
a VLAN ID of 300 on port1 and VLAN ID of 300 on port2 are allowed, but they aren’t connected. Their relationship is the
same as between any two FortiGate network interfaces.
FortiGate interfaces can’t have overlapping IP addresses, the IP addresses of all interfaces must be on different
subnets. This rule applies to both physical interfaces and to virtual interfaces, such as VLAN subinterfaces.

C and D

comments.content:
D is clearly right but I think C is also ok since the traffic sent by physical port1 is untagged:
https://kb.fortinet.com/kb/viewContent.do?externalId=FD30883

C is absolutely correct and A is wrong. B and D are tricky. Generally a layer 2 broadcast to mac FF:FF:FF:FF:FF will be broadcast by the switch to all ports in the same VLAN, so forgetting about any layer 3, B is correct in that respect. However it depends on how the FGT reacts and if it drops the bcast only if they are different subnets, technically it shouldnt but it must. Again we are talking about layer 2 broadcast address.

For D, this is correct but kind of makes B even more likely to be correct.... annoying question :D

If you put 2 switch ports in the same VLAN and connect 2 hosts but place them in separate subnets you will absolutely see the bcast frames from both on both on wireshark.

Actually on reflecting, D being correct and B being wrong together make more sense than B being correct and if it is D cannot be wrong really. So C and D...

I actually found it here: fortinetguru.com/2016/12/vlans/ - see the last statement

C is also correct. FortiGate_Infrastructure_6.4 page 158
Frames sent or received by the physical interface segment are never tagged. They belong to that is called the native VLAN (VLAN ID 0).

discussion.content: B is wrong because are not part of the same broadcast domain (different subnet) , C is wrong because native vlan is a vlan passed to tag untagged traffic on the interface and on port1 is not declared. A) is wrong because not allowed traffic between different interface . Only D is ok...
A and D are Correct

choices.A: Access to the social networking web filter category was explicitly blocked to all users.

choices.B: The action on firewall policy ID 1 is set to warning.

discussion.content: Answer is 100% C. Tested on my Fortigate by setting Social Networking web filter category to Authenticate and applying that to a high priority policy with full SSL inspection enabled. First action listed in raw log for that IP was blocked, then authentication page popped up, entered credentials for user and then a log with action passthrough was generated.

Selected Answer: C
The answer to this one is C.
A is incorrect. The web filter category is not explicitly blocked since it is allowed the second time around.
B is incorrect. The policy is not what is interacting, the web filter profile is. The question even refers to the "web filter logs."
D is incorrect. The name of the web filter profile is "all_users_web" not the firewall policy.
C is correct
The correct answer is A. traffic to the site in the social networking catagory is blocked for all_users_web.
B is correct: When you set the Warning action, you will see firstly the blocked and if you click on the web page to continue to the site you will see another passthrough.
